Use summation/sigma notation to write sums in a condensed way
Estimate distance traveled with a velocity function and connect the distance problem to the area problem

subsubsection.title: The Area Problem

example.statement:
Consider the function y=x^2 on the interval [0,1].
Use four rectangles to approximate the area under the parabola y=x^2 from x=0 to x=1; start from the left endpoint, x=0.
Left-rectangle approximiation for y=x^2. Slide n to see different approximations (hide the menu by pressing the arrows).
Now start from the right endpoint, x=1, and use four rectangles to approximate the area under the parabola.
Right-rectangle approximiation for y=x^2. Slide n to see different approximations (hide the menu by pressing the arrows).
Now use eight rectangles to approximate the area under y=x^2 from x=0 to x=1, using both left and right endpoints. Compare your estimates to the previous two calculations.

question.statement: What do you think would happen to our approximation of area if we used more rectangles?
question.solution: We would get a better approximation.

subsubsection.p: Generically, the process we used above has the following steps:

ol.li: Determine the length of the interval
Divide the interval into n equal subintervals
Find the area of each subinterval's rectangle
Sum the areas of the rectangles

ol.label: a
ol.li: If the interval we are concerned about is [a,b], and we are using n rectangles to approximate the area, how could we write the base length of each individual rectangle? Denote the length by \Delta x
Let a=x_0. How could we express x_1? How about x_2? What about a generic x_i, where 1\leq i\leq n?
Let f(x_i) be the function value at x_i. Using the previous two exercises, write an expression for S_n, the sum of areas of our approximating rectangles.

subsubsection.p: From this, we can generalize to two special situations.

assemblage.title: Left Rectangle Approximation
assemblage.p: The left rectangle approximation for the area under the curve f(x) on the interval [a,b] (using n rectangles) is given by f(x_0)\Delta x + f(x_1)\Delta x + \cdots + f(x_{n-2})\Delta x + f(x_{n-1})\Delta x or, in sigma notation, \ds \sum_{n=0}^{n-1} f(x_i)\Delta x The nth left rectangle approximation is denoted L_n.

assemblage.title: Right Rectangle Approximation
assemblage.p: The right rectangle approximation for the area under the curve f(x) on the interval [a,b] (using n rectangles) is given by f(x_1)\Delta x + f(x_2)\Delta x + \cdots + f(x_{n-1})\Delta x + f(x_n)\Delta x or, in sigma notation, \ds \sum_{n=1}^{n} f(x_i)\Delta x The nth right rectangle approximation is denoted R_n.

subsubsection.title: Sigma Notation
subsubsection.p: Sigma notation is a shorthand way to write sums. For example, for the left-rectangle approximation L_4, instead of writing L_4 = f(x_0)\Delta x + f(x_1)\Delta x + f(x_2)\Delta x + f(x_3)\Delta x we would write \ds L_4 = \sum_{n=0}^3 f(x_i)\Delta x Here, i=0 refers to the starting index, and n=3 is called the ending index.

subsection.title: In Class

example.statement: For f(x) = x^2 on [0,1], show that the sum of the areas of the upper approximating rectangles approaches \dfrac{1}{3}, i.e. \ds \lim_{n\to\infty} R_n = \dfrac{1}{3}.

subsection.definition: Area Under a Curve Area The area of the region S that lies under the graph of the continuous function f is the limit of the sum of the areas of approximating rectangles: A = \lim_{n\to\infty} L_n = \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} f(x_i)\Delta x or A = \lim_{n\to\infty} R_n = \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n} f(x_i)\Delta x

example.statement:
Let A be the area of the region that lies under the graph of f(x) = x^3 between x = 1 and x=b, where 1\leq b\leq 3
Using left endpoints, find an expression for A as a limit; do not evaluate the limit.
Estimate the area when b=3 by taking sample points to be midpoints and using four subintervals.
The expression \ds \lim_{n\to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \dfrac{3}{n} \sqrt{1+\dfrac{3i}{n}} gives the area of a region; describe such a region. Do not try to evaluate the limit.
example.solution: One possible description is the function f(x) = \sqrt{1+x} on the interval [0,3]

example.statement: If a curve measures the rate of change of some function, what is the explicit connection between the area under the curve on a given interval and the total change of the function on that interval?
example.solution: The net area between the rate of change curve and the axis gives the total change of the function on the interval.
